reasoning: The critique targets a genuinely load-bearing part of the paper’s intuitive engine in Section 2.4: the move from “many morally important dimensions” to “value is highly right-skewed so mostly-great futures are rare,” illustrated via a product-of-(roughly)-independent-factors toy model. If strong positive correlations made near-all-dimensions-high outcomes common, that would significantly weaken that specific support for “no easy eutopia.” However, the overall position is not solely dependent on near-independence: the essay also argues for fussiness via population ethics, digital beings, scale, fat-tailed value-efficiency, and (especially) Section 3’s systematic claims about bounded/unbounded value functions. So falsifying near-independence wouldn’t collapse the whole thesis. On strength, the objection is plausible but underdeveloped: it asserts correlation could be strong without arguing empirically or theoretically that correlations would be sufficiently high, stable under radical future variation, and in the right places (some key ‘single flaw’ risks—e.g., population ethics choices, rights of digital beings, space resource allocation—could be weakly correlated or even trade off). Also, multiplicative models can still produce heavy skew under correlated factors, and the paper presents the product model as an explanatory toy model rather than a strict premise. Relevance is moderate-high because it probes an internal modeling assumption Forethought uses across its EV decomposition/product-of-factors methodology (Tier 2) and could refine how they model flourishing-risk distributions, even if it doesn’t directly resolve a listed Tier 3 dispute. Overall, it’s a clear, constructive internal critique but currently not strong enough to seriously endanger the main conclusion.
title: "Correlated Drivers Undermine Independence Assumption"
